node.title: How to set target value in eigensolver?
node.bodyText:
Is there an interface in Moose to set the target value in eigen solver?
I know it is possible in SLEPc, I couldn't figure out how to set it in Moose.

Hello
Do you mean setting a target value then adjusting parameters to make the solution be this target value?
Or do you mean selecting an eigenmode by selecting a known eigenvalue?

I would look at this example modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/modal_analysis/modal.i.
We can pass any petsc/slepc options using the interface
petsc_options_iname = '-st_type -eps_target -st_pc_type -st_pc_factor_mat_solver_type'
petsc_options_value = 'sinvert 0 lu mumps'
Thank you for the info. I didn't realize the solution is right there.

node.title: New Material Definition

node.bodyText:
hello
The headers seem to be nested under src/materials. We expect them to be under include/materials here
That's probably not the problem.
Did the application recompile correctly? Can you use the other objects you created?
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud
It compiled correctly and I am getting the same error "Not a registered object".
I have tried to put in include/materials but the same error persists.
A few months back, I defined in the same way src/materials and it was working correctly. I re-installed the moose as I was some other issues with login-id
Now after re-installment I am facing this issue

ok so:

save all your work with git commit
git clean -Xfd in the root directory of the app
recompile

if it still doesnt work, same but git cleaning moose as well before recompiling

Hi @GiudGiud
It worked
Thank you so much for the help

node.title: Applying gradient after time interval
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am trying to implement a spatial gradient (DD_Scaling) after a time interval. Part of the code looks like this:
"[./Scaling_DD]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'DD_Scaling'
    material_property_names = 'DD_bl hbl1'
    expression =  (hbl1*DD_bl )'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./density]
    type = GenericFunctionMaterial
    material_property_names = 'DD_Scaling'
    prop_names = 'density'
    prop_values = 'if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)'
    #outputs = exodus
  [../]"

However, GenericFunctionMaterial does not allow using a derivativeparsedmaterial into it. So what is the way to use a spatial gradient after a time interval?
I appreciate your response. Thanks.

Hello
I think a parsedMaterial will do well for defining this 'if' condition, using the expression parameter

@GiudGiud changed the code to
[./Scaling_DD]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'DD_Scaling'
    material_property_names = 'DD_bl hbl1'
    expression =  (hbl1*DD_bl )'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
[./density]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'density'
    material_property_names = 'DD_Scaling'
    expression = 'if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)'
    #outputs = exodus
  [../]

However, now showing error:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
if(t<150,0,DD_Scaling)
DD_Scaling
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier

Any solution for that?
Thanks.

how old is your version of moose?
I think t is not recognized by the ParsedMaterial
You ll need to define t as a function, with a ParsedFunction with use_xyzt set to true for example
@GiudGiud I did not update MOOSE recently. good news is solved the issue. We need ParsedFunction with FunctionAux. appreciate, cheers.

node.title: Code developed to Integrate a Gradient on a Surface
node.bodyText:
I have modified some code to determine the value of the surface integral pictured. The values that are being calculated from the code as developed are not in total agreement with the reference value. Would you be as so kind to review what I have modified and point out the potential errors that I have that may be causing my errors?
SideDiffusiveFluxDotNormIntegralDotComp_crab_C.txt
SideDiffusiveFluxDotNormIntegralDotComp_crab_h.txt

Hello
There's a lot in this expression. is u_tau the tangeantial component to a vector field, tangeant to the surface? and ns the normal? what is n_y ?

Thank you for taking a look at it. You are correct, n is the normal, n_y is the normal to the y-axis. I will have to verify u_tau, I believe it is the u component tangential to the surface, where its value may be zero at the surface, but its derivative is not necessarily zero.
I would recommend you remove the "diffusivity gradient product" routines, and write down the expression directly

Would you be able to provide a simple example of writing down an expression directly that involves a derivative with respect to the normal? I'm not sure of how to write it in the syntax required by MOOSE.

sure, use the chain rule
du/dn = du/dx dx/dn + du/dy dy/dn ...

then dx/dn is 1/n_x

node.title: Full response function with part of a side on a free BC
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I'm working on the full response function of a block of ice where I'd like to keep part of one side free while the rest of that side is on a null Dirichlet BC. I've been generating a mesh on the fly, and then using SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator to target the specific area I'm interested in and further SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator to apply a BC to this zone. It works just fine when I apply a non-null Dirichlet BC on that small zone, but as soon as I was to keep it free with the rest of the side on a null Dirichlet, it's keeping it to a null Dirichlet too instead of letting it move. Do you know how I could prevent the decoupling_bottom boundary to be set to 0 instead of staying free? I've been searching the discussions and the doc but couldn't find a fix.
The input file can be found here
Thank you a lot in advance for your help! :)

Hello
Looks like the displacement BCs are being controlled by this function
  [bed_coupling_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '${bed_coupled} = 0'
  []
[]

in this Control
  [bed_not_coupled]
    type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
    conditional_function = bed_coupling_function
    disable_objects = 'BCs::dirichlet_decoupling_bottom_x BCs::dirichlet_decoupling_bottom_y BCs::dirichlet_decoupling_bottom_z'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

this function is always '0 = 0' which I m not sure is even a valid function.
Maybe try to have
expression = 'if(${bed_coupled}>-1e-6, 1, 0)'
so we dont need to wonder about the parsing rounding

That's only because bed_coupled is a boolean given at the top of the input file, to be able to turn it on and off on a simulation basis. Then part of the bed is coupled or not during the whole simulation. And it's not function of any variable, and is modified by the user here.
So that if bed_coupled is False then the three dirchlet_decoupling_bottom BCs (x, y, z) are being disabled.

So that if bed_coupled is False then the three dirchlet_decoupling_bottom BCs (x, y, z) are being disabled.

and this part does not work currently right? They still seem to be set?
if you comment out the BC, is the displacement still blocked to 0?

and this part does not work currently right? They still seem to be set?

yes, somehow as if the new boundary created with 'decoupling_bottomand the explicitreplace=true` is actually not truly replacing it... If I set a non-null BC on this boundary, it takes over the null one, but if I just want to keep it free, it's stuck on the null BC set around it...

if you comment out the BC, is the displacement still blocked to 0?

exactly, as if the boundary decoupling_bottom was added on top of the bottom that's on the entire face, but not actually replacing it.

Sidesets don't replace other sidesets that pre exist.
Edit you did set replace=true.
What does paraview show? It shows the sidesets
You can use a ParsedGenerateSideset to cut one sideset out from another

This is decoupling_botom:

And this is bottom:

So it definitely looks like it's not being replaced..
Maybe the issue comes from the nodesets? This feels odd:

Node sets are being created on the decoupling_bottom side but they're called nodelist_6. I'm wondering if that has anything to do with my issue...

Nodesets do get converted back to sidesets by default
And some BCs like displacements are applied on nodesets not sidesets
So yes it is likely tied to nodesets

But so the decoupling_bottom sideset should be tied to nodelist_6.. And that's the case since when I set a non-null BC then it works fine. Do you mean that when no displacement BC is set on decoupling_bottom then the nodeset associated to this boundary (nodelist_6) is being removed for the bottom nodeset to take over?

You can use a ParsedGenerateSideset to cut one sideset out from another

Ok I'll try that. I decided not to initially since this involves hard coding geometry dimensions rather than calling a boundary. It would work here with a flat bed but would get much harder to use on a more complex geometry...

Indeed when I look at nodesets only, the decoupling area still has the bottom nodeset:

while having the nodelist_6 too:

So I guess there's some nodeset priority happening in the background, where the bottom nodeset takes over when the decoupling nodeset is left free.
I'll try and find a way to get the replacement to really work, both on sidesets and nodesets.
I face the same problem of non-free BC with ParsedGenerateSideset..

After some more testing it really feels like replace = true of SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator doesn't actually replace the sideset (nor the nodeset)
EDIT: it feels like it was the mesh refinement that prevented the sideset to be removed. If I remove the mesh refinement then sideset get replaced, but still not nodesets...
I was looking for a replace in NodeSetsFromSideSetsGenerator but doesn't seem like the way to go.

even if it does not work, I think there is a way forward:

create the limited sideset decoupling_bottom
delete bottom using a BoundaryDeletionGenerator
re-add bottom using a ParsedGenerateSideset, using the ParseExpression to exclude decoupling_bottom

I think we need in ParsedGenerateSideset an "exclude_boundaries" parameter. I can work on this soon. This will make creating bottom while excluding decoupling_bottom easier

you can try new option for excluding a boundary from consideration when making a new boundary here
#28550

node.title: Making changes in degradation function:
node.bodyText:
So, I am working on a crystal plasticity phase field problem. I based my code on input file: combined/test/tests/phase_field_fracture/crack2d_aniso.i
Here, and in many other files, a very simple degradation function was defined as:
[./degradation]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = degradation
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    expression = '(1.0-c)^2*(1.0 - eta) + eta'
    constant_names       = 'eta'
    constant_expressions = '1.0e-6'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]

I wanted to modify it as:
[./degradation]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = degradation
    args = 'c effective_plastic_strain'
    function = '(1.0-c)^(2*effective_plastic_strain/critical_effective_plastic_strain)*(1.0 - eta) + eta'
    constant_names       = 'eta critical_effective_plastic_strain'
    constant_expressions = '1.0e-3 1.0e-2'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]

For that, I defined the "effective_plastic_strain" in my .C UOBasedCP file and for crystal plasticity setup, it works perfectly
_effective_plastic_strain(declareProperty<Real>("effective_plastic_strain")),
_effective_plastic_strain_old(
        getMaterialPropertyOld<Real>("effective_plastic_strain"))

and also can take it as output:
[./effective_plastic_strain]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[./effective_plastic_strain]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    variable = effective_plastic_strain
    property = effective_plastic_strain
    execute_on = timestep_end
  [../]

So, with these modifications, I tried to run my phase field code. I just wanted to confirm if this approach is correct?
The other approach I could think of was that I calculate the dDdc and d2Dd2c inside the .C files, but that will be too hectic, and there are no implementations like that that could be found.
I could not find much about the coupled variables that were implemented that way I did, even when looking in different .i files.

Hello
Looks fine to me. @dschwen any thoughts on this phase field problem?

I wanted to modify it as:

looks fine but the second one uses deprecated parameter names.
Function should be expression
f_name should be property_name. and so on
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/DerivativeParsedMaterial.html

node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, I would like to know why this expression is not working. I would like the function to be 50, 100, 150, 200 and 300, for the different timings of 1, 2, 3, 4 and more, respectively.
[./path_x]
type = ParsedFunction
expression = 'if(t<1,50,if(t<2,100,if(t<3,150,if(t<4,200,300))))'
[../]

Hello
Are you checking at t=1 exactly? Since you used < it would have jumped already to the next value
Expression looks correct to me
Hello, my apologies, it is correct and it is working, my error was in "path_z" and that is why I could not see the behaviour that I wanted. Thanks! :)

So below is the kks model(material block) I used to evaluate how misfit strains can contribute to the variant selection of particular precipitates. I imported the mesh from that simulation in crystal plasticity model(which I am working on now). i wanted to add the eigen strain to the mechanical strain in this model.
[Materials]
  # simple toy free energies
  [./f1]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_1
    args = 'c1'
    function = '100.0*(c1-0.3333)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 1
  [./elastic_free_energy_1]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase1
    f_name = fe_1
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 1
  [./Total_energy_1]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F1
    sum_materials = 'fc_1 fe_1'
    args = 'c1'
  [../]

  [./f2]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_2
    args = 'c2'
    function = '100.0*(c2-0.3333)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 2
  [./elastic_free_energy_2]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase2
    f_name = fe_2
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 2
  [./Total_energy_2]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F2
    sum_materials = 'fc_2 fe_2'
    args = 'c2'
  [../]

  [./f3]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fc_3
    args = 'c3'
    function = '5.0*(c3-0.20)^2'
  [../]
  # Elastic energy of the phase 3
  [./elastic_free_energy_3]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    base_name = phase3
    f_name = fe_3
    args = ' '
  [../]
  # Total free energy of the phase 3
  [./Total_energy_3]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    f_name = F3
    sum_materials = 'fc_3 fe_3'
    args = 'c3'
  [../]

  # Switching functions for each phase
  # h1(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h1]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta1
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h1
  [../]
  # h2(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h2]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta2
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h2
  [../]
  # h3(eta1, eta2, eta3)
  [./h3]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMultiPhaseMaterial
    phase_etas = eta3
    all_etas = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_name = h3
  [../]

  # Coefficients for diffusion equation
  [./Dh1]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h1'
    function = D*h1
    f_name = Dh1
  [../]
  [./Dh2]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h2'
    function = D*h2
    f_name = Dh2
  [../]
  [./Dh3]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    material_property_names = 'D h3'
    function = D*h3
    f_name = Dh3
  [../]

  # Barrier functions for each phase
  [./g1]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta1
    function_name = g1
  [../]
  [./g2]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta2
    function_name = g2
  [../]
  [./g3]
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    g_order = SIMPLE
    eta = eta3
    function_name = g3
  [../]

  # constant properties
  [./constants]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'L    kappa  D  misfit  W'
    prop_values = '0.3  0.01   1  0.005  0.01'
  [../]

  #Mechanical properties
  [./Stiffness_phase1]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '1982 534 496 1606 605 1788 985 1056 388'    
    base_name = phase1
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]
  [./Stiffness_phase2]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '1606 534 605 1982 496 1788 1056 985 388'
    base_name = phase2
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]
  [./Stiffness_phase3]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '2008.5 448.9 918.5 2008.5 918.5 1538.7 779.8 779.8 309.9'    
    base_name = phase3
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]

  [./stress_phase1]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase1
  [../]
  [./stress_phase2]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase2
  [../]
  [./stress_phase3]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    base_name = phase3
  [../]

  [./strain_phase1]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase1
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain1
  [../]
  [./strain_phase2]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase2
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain2
  [../]
  [./strain_phase3]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = phase3
  [../]

  [./eigen_strain1]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    base_name = phase1
    eigen_base = '1 0 0 0 0 0'
    prefactor = misfit
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain1
  [../]

  [./eigen_strain2]
    type = ComputeEigenstrain
    base_name = phase2
    eigen_base = '0 1 0 0 0 0'
    prefactor = misfit
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain2
  [../]


  # Generate the global stress from the phase stresses
  [./global_stress]
    type = MultiPhaseStressMaterial
    phase_base = 'phase1 phase2 phase3'
    h          = 'h1     h2     h3'
  [../]

  [./global_strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
[]

it should be found now?
you define it with this
  [./constants]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'L    kappa  D  misfit  W'
    prop_values = '0.3  0.01   1  0.005  0.01'
  [../]
Yeah my bad, it worked now. Thanks
Just a quick question if i have a precipitate with eigen strain as shown by the picture below what will be the correct input in my script for misfit?
it's the wrong type right now,. it s a real and this can be represented as a RealVectorValue (just the diagonal) or a RealTensorValue
so not only would you need to change the type of misfit in the input, but also change the code to accept misfit as a vector or tensor

So I need to change my input to;
[./constants]
type = RealVectorValue
prop_names  = 'L    kappa  D  misfit  W'
prop_values = '0.3  0.01   1  0.005  0.01'
[../]
And also change the source code to accept this vector value type if I get you right. And I guess that would be in the ComputeEigenStrainValue.C
no you need to change the input to use a Generic.... (the one for Tensor or vector) for misfit only, not L kappa D or W

node.title: Error while working on creating a Moose App
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
So, I installed the MOOSE from the website and after that, I followed the instructions given in "https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/new_users.html" to develop my moose app, while at step "./moose/scripts/stork.sh YourAppName", it gave me issues related to using GIT while creating the moose app:

  git config --global user.name "Your Name"

I utilized the discussions of threads #27575 and #27612 to solve it.
My steps were:
~/projects/moose/scripts/stork.sh crystal_phase_field

cd /home/aayush/projects/crystal_phase_field

After this:

and it seemed to work. But the real problem came after this:
I made a folder at: """/home/aayush/projects/crystal_phase_field/src/cp_models""" and inside it defined a new .C file named: CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSSKapoor.C and saved its .h file named CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSSKapoor.h at: """/home/aayush/projects/crystal_phase_field/include/cp_models""". This C file was made on top of already existing """CrystalPlasticitySlipRateGSS.C""" file already present in moose and also tested and working using solid_mechanics-opt.
Obviously, I already made the changes in makefile to activate the solid_mechanics and phase_field modules:

Hello
when you add a new module you need to git clean -Xfd your application before recompiling
